results.content: The course is well outdated and the instructor does very little to take a student to master MVC from scratch. A lot of the code is prewritten and the instructor just generally goes through what he has written without explaining much of the thought process behind it. The fundamentals of MVC are there, but much of how it is used today is lost. At times it gets very repetitive or on the contrary an important principle is summed up in a single sentence. All course files are packed into a massive zip and are not indexed, making them hard to find. Disappointed to see that the course has not been updated since it was launched even though the instructor has changed something just to keep it more relevant in the searches.
results.content_html: The course is well outdated and the instructor does very little to take a student to master MVC from scratch. A lot of the code is prewritten and the instructor just generally goes through what he has written without explaining much of the thought process behind it. The fundamentals of MVC are there, but much of how it is used today is lost. At times it gets very repetitive or on the contrary an important principle is summed up in a single sentence. All course files are packed into a massive zip and are not indexed, making them hard to find. Disappointed to see that the course has not been updated since it was launched even though the instructor has changed something just to keep it more relevant in the searches.

results.content: It was a really good class. Just a couple suggestions. Before someone starts into the actual coding or following, give a list or document of needed resources to get the most out of the class. For instance, 1. You need SQL Server, and here are the SQL queries to build and populate all tables. 2. You need Visual Studio version ? with these ADD IN's! "I didn't know I'd need database access for the class, so I was missing some elements."  3. You will need an IIS Manager if you want to complete step ##.   This is just a suggestion, but I would have gotten more out of the class if I'd been set up with them.
results.content_html: It was a really good class. Just a couple suggestions. Before someone starts into the actual coding or following, give a list or document of needed resources to get the most out of the class. For instance, 1. You need SQL Server, and here are the SQL queries to build and populate all tables. 2. You need Visual Studio version ? with these ADD IN's! "I didn't know I'd need database access for the class, so I was missing some elements." 3. You will need an IIS Manager if you want to complete step ##. This is just a suggestion, but I would have gotten more out of the class if I'd been set up with them.

results.content: The ending of course is very abrupt.  We know of end, just because there are no more lessons left.  But there are no winding up remarks, no announcement of completion of course.  This could be improved.  At many places, the proper referencing was missing.  For example, at the end, the reference to IIS was sudden.  Also, actual examples of code building and certain small projects working could have helped better understanding, instead of only covering the topics.  But still, whatever is covered in the course is useful and we can try to apply it in actual practice.

results.content: The course content was great! The demonstrations were clear and well done. The things I didn't like as much about it were that the teacher pastes a lot of code and doesn't write it out in front of you. He goes back through and explains it though. But I learn better when I see the teacher type it out instead of pasting big chunks. The only other thing I didn't like about the course was that in a lot of instances, someone might not know much about the particular thing he's talking about and he basically says something like "I will show you how to use Scaffolding Templates" (Scaffolding Templates being the thing the user is unfamiliar with). He'll then show how to do it, but the user may not even know what Scaffolding Templates are in the first place. So if he were to improve that, all he'd have to do is give an explanation about what he's about to do before just jumping in and doing it. Overall, a  good course and very helpful for anyone new to MVC who already knows C#.
results.content_html: The course content was great! The demonstrations were clear and well done. The things I didn't like as much about it were that the teacher pastes a lot of code and doesn't write it out in front of you. He goes back through and explains it though. But I learn better when I see the teacher type it out instead of pasting big chunks. The only other thing I didn't like about the course was that in a lot of instances, someone might not know much about the particular thing he's talking about and he basically says something like "I will show you how to use Scaffolding Templates" (Scaffolding Templates being the thing the user is unfamiliar with). He'll then show how to do it, but the user may not even know what Scaffolding Templates are in the first place. So if he were to improve that, all he'd have to do is give an explanation about what he's about to do before just jumping in and doing it. Overall, a good course and very helpful for anyone new to MVC who already knows C#.

results.content:
When i saw the instructor's name in this course, i pressed that 'Buy Now' button like crazy. It wasn't a surprise for me that he delivered another 5 star course.
This course includes everything you need to know to get started ( and  more ) with Asp.Net MVC.
Greate job once again Mister!
